title: Notice of A Home in Africa - context

content.description:
Announcement of the Universal Negro Improvement Association Calling for Members to Settle in Liberia, West Africa

The document reads as follows:

“Let’s Put it Over.”

A Home in Africa.

Notice to Members of Universal Negro Improvement Association.

All members of the Universal Negro Improvement Association who desire to go to Liberia, West Africa, to settle to help in the industrial, commercial and cultural development of the country, and who intend sailing September, October, December, 1924, or January, February, March, April or May, 1925, are requested to send in for application form to be filled out.

Address: Universal Negro Improvement Assn., Dept. E, 56 West 135th Street, New York City, USA.
The Marcus Garvey and UNIA Papers Project
content.question: Which of the following is most directly related to the development of the Universal Negro Improvement Association?

choices.label: An increase in racial integration and economic growth during the Great Migration resulted in the formation of organizations by African Americans.
Marcus Garvey encouraged African Americans to advance through self-determination and separatist Black institutions.
Black intellectuals such as W.E.B. Du Bois used symbols to represent African Americans’ separation from full citizenship in American society.
The expansion of the Black press played a significant role in providing news to the Black community and documenting African American life.

content.answer: Marcus Garvey encouraged African Americans to advance through self-determination and separatist Black institutions.
